Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, phone pressed to my ear as I tried to clarify a delivery date with the contractor. My mind was half on the conversation, half on the text I’d just received from my stepmother: “Can we talk tonight? Your dad’s been quiet lately.” I knew what she wanted—someone to listen, to reassure her, to check in and make sure everything was okay at home. But the project was behind schedule, and the contractor needed answers now. My boss expected me to keep things moving, to be available, to solve problems before they became crises. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. If I called home, I’d lose precious time and risk another delay. If I stayed focused on work, I’d be letting my family down, ignoring the subtle plea for support. My heart tugged in one direction, my professional pride in another, and I sat there, paralyzed, unable to choose which expectation to meet first.
